My family came to the United States to work and build their American Dream. The immigrant families living in our communities today deserve those same opportunities, and I'm proud to work to make that a reality.

That's why I introduced my bill - the Fairness for Immigrant Families Act. 

This bill will implement commonsense fixes to our immigration system that will help families stay together, crack down on fraud, and bring people out of the shadows.

These are serious problems, and we need to address them - but we can't repeat the ineffective Trump playbook that cruelly separated families and forced millions further into the shadows.   

We can treat families with dignity AND secure our border.

But we also shouldn't ignore the disorder we‚Äôve seen at the border ‚Äî we need stronger border security. 

As Attorney General and in the Senate, I've personally worked to crack down on human trafficking, drug smuggling, and coyotes at the border.
As the granddaughter of a baker from Mexico, it's personal to me. And it's the right thing to do for the families who call America home.

Today, there are families across the country that include Dreamers, TPS recipients, and essential workers who are central to our communities.    

They're our health care workers, our teachers, our farm workers - and they deserve a pathway to citizenship.

Our immigration system is broken.  

The only way to fix it is for us to stop talking past each other and work together to protect immigrant families and secure our border. üßµ

Because the next Iraq will be even worse.

We need accountability for those who got us into this war. But most of all we need to see all of our lives connected as part of the human fabric‚Äîto understand that the parent who loses a child in war could be us, that the child who is displaced could be our child.

The think tanks and lobbyists who pushed for it out of self-interest, the extremist ideologues who see war‚Äîand US domination‚Äîas part of the natural order, and the media who credulously amplify these views for ratings.
To truly be able to avoid another Iraq, we need a national reckoning with how we got into it the first place‚Äî

Much like the lost Iraqi lives lost were often ignored 20 years ago, we continue to ignore the pain and suffering of Black and Brown people in places like Syria, Yemen, Ethiopia, Myanmar, Haiti and more.
Claims from senior national security officials are reported as fact, even when no evidence for those claims is presented.
Our national media too often treat war as a game‚Äîa way to juice ratings as fewer Americans turn into TV news‚Äîrather than the most horrific state of conditions to be avoided at all costs.
Our spending on Pentagon waste and new weapons continues to rise uncontrollably‚Äîwith weapons contractors wielding more lobbying power than ever in Washington.
Instead of seeing China as a geopolitical challenge to be managed, politicians gin up jingoistic sentiment and nationalism to see who can be the most ‚Äúanti-China.‚Äù
Think tanks (often the same ones who cheerled the Iraq War) outflank each other to justify armed conflict and derail diplomacy with adversaries like Iran.
But most concerning, our foreign policy discourse remains fundamentally pro-war.
Many of the same people so eager to push for war now oppose taking care of the veterans who served in that war‚Äîfighting tooth and nail against legislation like the PACT Act.

Figures like John Bolton and Elliot Abrams continue to receive appointments to senior national security roles in our government. 

Many many more continue to receive some of the largest platforms in media.

We still have not had full accountability for the war crimes perpetrated, or for those responsible for cheerleading the war.

The perpetrators of this war‚ÄîGeorge W. Bush and Dick Cheney have faced no accountability for war crimes and continue to be accepted in Washington society.

20 years later, the Iraq War remains the biggest foreign policy disaster of our generation, one that took thousands of American lives and hundreds of thousands of Iraqi lives.

Have we fully learned the lessons from this failed war of aggression, or are we doomed to repeat it? üßµ
